headline: Must man first go mad in order to be sane?; The Self
leadPara: For a great many Americans, particularly young Americans, the 1960's were a time in which two of the deepest streams of consciousness--selfconsciousness and social consciousness--converged. The radical vision and energy of the sixties aimed at a fusion of ideas and experiences which the fifties had found either unrelated or incompatible: political freedom and personal ecstasy, activism and mysticism, voter-registration drives and mind-expanding drugs, sit-ins and love-ins.

headline: American in Everything but Geography
leadPara: PEOPLE argue about whether the Japanese have an inferiority complex or a superiority complex. I sometimes think they have neither; what they have is an "eriority complex." They just feel different from everybody else--sometimes superior, sometimes inferior, but always different. And this feeling of uniqueness, the feeling of being a separate people, isolated on a few islands anchored off the far coast of Asia, has been a part of the cement holding the group together.

headline: Purification of Nation's Waters Expected to Be Long and Costly; Purification of the Nation's Waters Expected to Be a Long and Costly Process
leadPara: Federal experts are finding that restoration of the nation's waters to something approaching satisfactory cleanliness is many years and many billions of dollars in the future.
abstract: G Hill survey finds cleaning up of nation's waters will be long and costly; condition of waters perhaps worse than it was 10 yrs ago; new types of pollution aggravate problem; antipollution efforts show promise but progress hinges on Cong decisions on controversial questions; illus of Indiana Harbor pollution; Nixon's $10-billion cleanup program seen as minor compared with ultimate prospective cost of over $100-billion for cleaning waterways; hearings on controversial bills to extend Fed pollution abatement powers to all waters and to require that states establish 'effluent standards' for every pollution source will soon begin but Cong opposition is expected; pub concern over pollution problem discussed; Fed efforts against pollution under '56 'conf law' allowing Fed officials to join states in pub hearing on conditions and formulate corrective programs, along with incentive program of Fed subsidies to localities for sewage treatment facilities, seen insufficient with continuous population growth; Fed Gen Acctg Office study concluding that despite $1.2-billion in Fed grants and $4.2-billion outlays by localities for treatment facilities there has been no improvement in water quality noted; state resistance to Fed intervention in establishing standards, govt lag in reimbursing cities and states for prefinanced treatment plants, resulting in $800-million debt, and inadequacy of direct Fed action against individual polluters discussed; new legis designed to increase Fed Govt's enforcement powers and creation of Fed agency to ease communities' financing problems discussed; Pres Johnson and Nixon's cleanup appropriations and continuation of $4-billion matching-grant subsidy program discussed; cost projections on basic natl pollution control needs generally provide for only 2-stage treatment, precipitation of gross solids and neutralizing of most other pollutants by biological or chem action; latter leaves some residual substances, nitrogen and phosphorous, that encourage plant growths; ultimate solution lies in 3-stage treatment which will remove practically all adulterants and leave slightly saline water at cost of twice as much as 2-stage program; new pollution areas, detergents which contain up to 44% phosphates and thermal pollution resulting from discharges of heated water into waterways, discussed; fact that cost estimates do not cover 2 big pollution sources, agr wastes and urban storm-water runoff, noted
